what: NEFSC Bottom Trawl Survey Data in {survdat}
title: Accessing Bottom Trawl Survey Data
text: R package {survdat} allows pull process NEFSC bottom trawl survey data. information {survdat} package can found : https://noaa-edab.github.io/survdat/index.html using package, need submit number ITD tickets: - Install Oracle Instant Client - Creation Oracle username password. Also request access NEFSCDB1 NEFSC_USERS databases ticket. - Install {ROracle} package must also behind NEFSC firewall (remote using VPN) R connect Oracle databases.

title: Accessing Bottom Trawl Survey Data
text: install {survdat} directly Github: package {dbutils} must also installed R connect Oracle databases. info {dbutils} : https://andybeet.github.io/dbutils/ connect Oracle databases pull survdat data function get_survdat_data() parameters include conversion factors (conversion.factor), species biological data (getBio), length data (getLengths) can set = TRUE FALSE.
code: remotes::install_github("NOAA-EDAB/survdat",build_vignettes = TRUE) remotes::install_github("andybeet/dbutils") channel <- dbutils::connect_to_database("server name","your username") survdat::get_survdat_data(channel)

title: Accessing Bottom Trawl Survey Data
text: Contact Andy Beet (andrew.beet@noaa.gov) issues {dbutils} {survdat} package help data pulls. access required tables SVDBS run {survdat} functions, function ‘get_survdat_data’ result following error: “Error .oci.GetQuery(conn, statment, data = data, prefetch = prefetch,…) ORA-00942: table view exist” occurs, contact Jakub Kircun PEMAD (jakub.cirkun@noaa.gov) SVDBS table access.

title: General report creation workflow
text: Even though seems complicated outset, creating report workflow R package save time streamline final product long run. reporting ecosystem inhabits R package, can easily accessed people (including ). create R package, start new R project, run usethis::create_package().

title: General report creation workflow
text: first step locate data. Data can come variety sources, including public websites, private databases, personal correspondence, existing R packages. Current data sources NEesp2 package include assessementdata package, survdat package (svdbs database), MRIP recreational catch data. data located, must formatted correctly. possible data already correct format, many cases data cleaning required. strongly suggested put data tidy format. Depending data source, data may may already species names stock regions assigned. example, survey data may strata rather stock region, scientific name rather common name. format data conform standard species naming region naming conventions. Finally, data properly formatted standard species region names, save data R package. data exists R object, can save package : usethis::use_data({data name}). allow access data quickly easily, without repeat data curation steps need use data.

title: General report creation workflow
text: data, next step begin visualizing displaying . like begin creating plot table one species (stock) . happy look plot table, generalize creation code function can applied input data. Finally, document function save package using roxygen2 package.

title: General report creation workflow
text: can create report template time create functions. recommend using bookdown package create template, can create section RMarkdown file, helps organization. recommend give template ability export save data figures used produced report. isn’t required, makes easier information report used contexts. Data can saved simple call write.csv saveRDS (large unwieldy data sets). Figures can saved setting figure cache global options, e.g., running knitr::opts_chunk$set(fig.path = "...") setup chunk. Put two forward slashes (//) path name, else figure names appended folder name, rather placed folder. Alternatively, also use png(...); ... ; dev.() save figure. desired, can create RMarkdown parameter toggle data/figure saving . find workflow necessitates frequently repeating code chunk(s) RMarkdown section(s) different inputs, consider making child document can call instead. streamline code reduce copy--paste errors. example, render_indicator function use regression reports calls child document rendered different indicator inputs time (inputs assigned generic names render_indicator called). Although required, strongly recommend create custom rendering function report template. allow set default values make parameters changed visible. template saved inst folder package (folder, ’s bookdown). Files inst folder made available root directory installed R package, package code can access template files calling system.file("{template name}", package = "{package name}")

what: 5. Deploy a suite of reports using Github Actions
title: General report creation workflow
text: using workflow generate large number reports, probably useful offload report generation onto remote runner Github Actions. generate reports Github Actions, devote memory time local machine report generation. However, likely hurdles getting Github Actions set successfully. Github Action workflow successfully renders reports deploys different repository. general steps workflow outlined . Github Actions running code remote environment, anything pre-installed. means install R, pandoc, packages need. found also configure settings command line bash get packages need install correctly. also check repo remote environment. Depending complexity reports, may need several dozen libraries, time takes install libraries adds . avoid bottleneck re-installing libraries need every time run Github Action, can cache packages adding cache step Github Actions workflow, save libraries remote environment allow loaded remote environment without re-installing. long cache accessed least week, continue live remote environment. Therefore, suggest making cache-maintaining Github Actions workflow pings cache regular schedule, don’t re-create cache every time go weeks without creating reports. rendering reports remote environment, must deploy reports repository github.com, else Github Action end, remote environment closed, reports gone. able successfully deploy reports Github Actions, must housekeeping set correct permissions. First, create personal access token going Settings –> Developer settings –> Personal access tokens Github account. Write token save somewhere, share anyone. Next, go repo setting Github Actions workflow. Go Settings –> Secrets add token name. must personal access token set every repo trying deploy Github Action. One issue deploying reports Github Actions one step fails, following steps Github Actions workflow canceled. means report rendering script breaks, reports deployed, even script breaks last report. Depending complexity report, may common untested edge case break code. Fortunately, work-around. wrap render function try(), script execute even reports properly created. course, reports fail render updated. can create report generation script integrates error logging code output information reports failed.

title: Indicator Sources for Northeast ESPs
text: {ecodata} R data package developed Ecosystems Dynamics Assessment Branch Northeast Fisheries Science Center use State Ecosystem (SOE) reporting. Indicators ecodata grouped following categories: Lower Trophic Levels, Megafauna, Oceanographic & Habitat, Economic & Social. Technical Documentation SOE indicators (https://noaa-edab.github.io/tech-doc/) contains relevant information indicator. {ecodata} can installed running following code RStudio derived data sets available package loaded environment. View available data sets using syntax ‘ecodata::…’ information SOE ecodata can found following links: https://github.com/NOAA-EDAB/ecodata?tab=readme-ov-file https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/new-england-mid-atlantic/ecosystems/state-ecosystem-reports-northeast-us-shelf

title: Indicator Sources for Northeast ESPs
text: NOAA 1/4° Daily Optimum Interpolation Sea Surface Temperature (OISST) long term Climate Data Record incorporates observations different platforms (satellites, ships, buoys Argo floats) regular global grid. dataset interpolated fill gaps grid create spatially complete map sea surface temperature. Daily, weekly, monthly data currently available September 1, 1981—present, updated every day. Raw data downloads available NetCDF4 format. (https://psl.noaa.gov/data/gridded/data.noaa.oisst.v2.highres.html)

title: Indicator Sources for Northeast ESPs
text: GLORYS12 global eddy-resolving physical ocean sea ice reanalysis 1/12° horizontal resolution covering 1993-present altimetry period, designed implemented framework Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). GLORYS includes daily monthly mean files temperature, salinity, currents, sea level, mixed layer depth ice parameters top bottom. Raw data access can found NetCDF4 format. (https://data.marine.copernicus.eu/product/GLOBAL_MULTIYEAR_PHY_001_030/services)

title: Indicator Sources for Northeast ESPs
text: Ocean-Colour Climate Change Initiative (OCCCI) provides satellite observations ocean color. daily level 3 (L3) mapped (4 km resolution, sinusoidally projected) OCCCI dataset composed merged SeaWIFS, MERIS, MODIS-Aqua, VIIRS Sentinel3A-OLCI global data. L3 OCCCI products include chlorophyll (CHL-CCI), remote sensing reflectance (Rrs(λ)), several inherent optical property products (IOPs). composite file browser WebGIS portal viewing manipulating data found https://www.oceancolour.org/

title: Indicator Sources for Northeast ESPs
text: OISST (daily, 1971-2020; monthly, 1991-2020) OCCCI (1991-present) data available NEFSC ERDDAP server (https://comet.nefsc.noaa.gov/erddap/info/index.html?page=1&itemsPerPage=1000). Publicly available ERDDAP datasets can accessed {rerddap} package (https://comet.nefsc.noaa.gov/erddap/info/index.html?page=1&itemsPerPage=1000). package {erddapXtracto} allows user extract data moving point time along user-supplied set longitude, latitude, depth time points, also extract data within polygon (time). (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rerddapXtracto/vignettes/UsingrerddapXtracto.html)

title: Using EDAB Utilities Functions for NE ESPs
text: vignette demonstrates use functions within EDABUtilities package (https://github.com/NEFSC/READ_EDAB_Utilities/tree/main) examining ecosystem data ESPs. example functions apply input data (.nc files) shape files utilized golden tilefish ESP.

what: Crop netCDFs of bottom temperature and bottom salinity to shape file of BTS strata
title: Using EDAB Utilities Functions for NE ESPs
text: Crops 2D netCDF based extent shape file.
code: crop_bottomT <- EDABUtilities::crop_nc_2d(data.in = c(here::here('data','glorys_bottomT.nc')),                             output.files = c(here::here('data','crop_glorys_bottomT.nc')),                             shp.file = here::here('shapefiles','BTS_STRATA.shp'),                             #area.names = c('01030'),                             var.name = 'bottomT',                             write.out = F)  terra::plot(crop_bottomT[[1]]) crop_bottomS <- EDABUtilities::crop_nc_2d(data.in = c(here::here('data','glorys_bottomS.nc')),                             output.files = c(here::here('data','crop_glorys_bottomS.nc')),                             shp.file = here::here('shapefiles','BTS_STRATA.shp'),                             var.name = 'bottomS',                             write.out = F)  terra::plot(crop_bottomS[[1]])

what: Make 2d summary time series: mean monthly bottom temperature in golden tilefish BTS strata
title: Using EDAB Utilities Functions for NE ESPs
text: Provides summary statistics 2d gridded data time series area.
code: monthly_bt <- EDABUtilities::make_2d_summary_ts(data.in = c(here::here('data','glorys_bottomT.nc')),                             output.files = c(here::here('data','GLORYS_monthly_bottomT.nc')),                             shp.file = here::here('shapefiles','BTS_STRATA.shp'),                             var.name = 'bottomT',                             area.names = c('01030', '01040', '01070', '01080', '01110', '01120',                                             '01140', '01150', '01670', '01680', '01710', '01720',                                             '01750', '01760'),                             statistic = 'mean',                             agg.time = 'days',                             tz = NA,                             touches = TRUE,                             write.out = F)  ggplot2::ggplot(monthly_bt[[1]],ggplot2::aes(x = time, y= value))+   ggplot2::geom_line(lwd = 1)+    ggplot2::labs(title = 'Monthly Bottom Temperature in GTF Strata') +   ggplot2::xlab('Month') +   ggplot2::ylab('Bottom Temperature') +   ggplot2::theme_bw() +   ggplot2::facet_wrap(~area)

what: Make 2d summary time series: mean daily bottom salinity in golden tilefish BTS strata
title: Using EDAB Utilities Functions for NE ESPs
text: Provides summary statistics 2d gridded data time series area.
code: daily_bS <- EDABUtilities::make_2d_summary_ts(data.in = c(here::here('data','glorys_bottomS.nc')),                    output.files = c(here::here('data','GLORYS_daily_bottomS.nc')),                    shp.file = here::here('shapefiles','BTS_STRATA.shp'),                    var.name = 'bottomS',                    area.names = c('01030', '01040', '01070', '01080', '01110', '01120',                                             '01140', '01150', '01670', '01680', '01710', '01720',                                             '01750', '01760'),                    statistic = 'mean',                    agg.time = 'days',                    tz = NA,                    touches = TRUE,                    write.out = F)  ggplot2::ggplot(daily_bS[[1]],ggplot2::aes(x = time, y= value))+   ggplot2::geom_line(lwd = 1)+    ggplot2::labs(title = 'Daily Bottom Salinity in GTF Strata') +   ggplot2::xlab('Days') +   ggplot2::ylab('Bottom Salinity') +   ggplot2::theme_bw() +   ggplot2::facet_wrap(~area)

what: Make 2d gridded time series: calculate number of days (nd) above a bottom temperature threshold (14C) in the golden tilefish BTS strata
title: Using EDAB Utilities Functions for NE ESPs
text: Provides data frame degree-day family statistics
code: dd <- EDABUtilities::make_2d_deg_day_ts(data.in = c(here::here('data','glorys_bottomT.nc')),                               output.files = c(here::here('data','GLORYS_monthly_bottomT.nc')),                               shp.file = here::here('shapefiles','BTS_STRATA.shp'),                               var.name = 'bottomT',                               area.names = c('01030', '01040', '01070', '01080', '01110', '01120',                                              '01140', '01150', '01670', '01680', '01710', '01720',                                              '01750', '01760'),                    ref.value = 14,                    type = 'above',                    statistic = 'nd',                    write.out = F)  dd_df = dplyr::bind_rows(dd)  ggplot2::ggplot(dd_df,ggplot2::aes(x = ls.id, y = value, fill = area))+   ggplot2::geom_bar(stat = 'identity', position = ggplot2::position_dodge(width = 1.0))+   ggplot2::labs(title = 'Number of days above 14C', fill = "Strata Number") +   ggplot2::xlab('GTF Strata') +   ggplot2::ylab('Days') +   ggplot2::theme_bw()

title: Using MRIP Data for Recreational Indicators
text: Data pulls NOAA Fisheries’ Marine Recreational Information Program (MRIP) can done MRIP Query Tool (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/data-tools/recreational-fisheries-statistics-queries). time, queries must saved csv loaded R. raw data includes lines metadata description format nicely. following lines code remove extra information modifies remaining data columns reading csv file. files used vignette found ‘data-raw’ folder package. Catch, landings, effort data can read one file multiple years. Directed trips must downloaded year interest. vignette shows example data pulls plots used 2025 black sea bass ESP report card: - Total Recreational Catch - Total Recreational Trips - Recreational Effort (proportion trips targeting black sea bass) - Total Recreational Landings
code: # catch data mrip_catch <- read.csv(here::here('data-raw/mrip_BLACK_SEA_BASS_catch_series.csv'),                                   skip = 46, # of rows you want to ignore                                   na.strings = ".") |>   janitor::clean_names(case = "all_caps")  # landings data mrip_landing <- read.csv(here::here('data-raw/mrip_BLACK_SEA_BASS_harvest.csv'),                          skip = 46, # of rows you want to ignore                          na.strings = ".") |>   janitor::clean_names(case = "all_caps")  # effort data  mrip_effort <- read.csv(here::here('data-raw/mrip_effort_series.csv'),                         skip = 44, # of rows you want to ignore                         na.strings = ".") |>   janitor::clean_names(case = "all_caps")  # trips files path = (here::here('data-raw/mrip_directed_trips'))  files <- list.files(path = path,                      pattern = utils::glob2rx('mrip*.csv'),                     full.names = TRUE)

title: Using {survdat} for Bottom Trawl Indicators
text: package contains functions producing bottom trawl indicators {survdat} data pulls: swept area biomass, stratified mean biomass, species condition, diet, range. vignette provides example output data tables plots using functions. information accessing {survdat} data, see vignette “Accessing Bottom Trawl Survey Data”.

title: Using {survdat} for Bottom Trawl Indicators
text: Uses ‘species_condition’ ‘plot_condition’ functions R/create_condition_indicator.R R/plot_condition.R
code: condition <- species_condition(data = NEesp2::survdat_subset, LWparams = LWparams, species.codes = species.codes) ## Joining with `by = join_by(STRATUM)` ## Joining with `by = join_by(count)` bsb_condition <- condition %>%   subset(Species == 'Black sea bass') head(bsb_condition) ## # A tibble: 6 × 8 ##   Species        EPU    YEAR DATA_VALUE nCond     sd variance INDICATOR_NAME ##   <chr>          <chr> <dbl>      <dbl> <int>  <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>          ## 1 Black sea bass GB     1994      0.983     4 0.0330  0.00109 mean condition ## 2 Black sea bass GB     1999      0.960    15 0.0330  0.00109 mean condition ## 3 Black sea bass GB     2000      0.982     4 0.0330  0.00109 mean condition ## 4 Black sea bass GB     2003      0.965     8 0.0330  0.00109 mean condition ## 5 Black sea bass GB     2005      0.944    13 0.0330  0.00109 mean condition ## 6 Black sea bass GB     2007      0.962     7 0.0330  0.00109 mean condition plot_condition(data = bsb_condition, var = 'Black sea bass')

what: Species Range - Black sea bass in fall
title: Using {survdat} for Bottom Trawl Indicators
text: Uses ‘species_range’ function R/create_bottomtrawl_indicators.R
code: range <- species_range(data = NEesp2::survdat_subset, species = NEesp2::species) ## Joining with `by = join_by(SVSPP)` bsb_range <- range %>%   subset(SPECIES == 'BLACK SEA BASS') %>%   subset(SEASON == 'FALL') %>%   subset(INDICATOR_NAME == c('range_lat','range_lon')) head(bsb_range) ## # A tibble: 6 × 7 ##    YEAR SEASON INDICATOR_NAME DATA_VALUE SPECIES        SVSPP INDICATOR_UNITS ##   <dbl> <chr>  <chr>               <dbl> <chr>          <dbl> <chr>           ## 1  1983 FALL   range_lat            5.33 BLACK SEA BASS   141 degrees         ## 2  1983 FALL   range_lon            5.93 BLACK SEA BASS   141 degrees         ## 3  1984 FALL   range_lat            5.67 BLACK SEA BASS   141 degrees         ## 4  1984 FALL   range_lon            5.2  BLACK SEA BASS   141 degrees         ## 5  1985 FALL   range_lat            6.57 BLACK SEA BASS   141 degrees         ## 6  1985 FALL   range_lon            5.58 BLACK SEA BASS   141 degrees bsb_range %>%   ggplot2::ggplot(ggplot2::aes(x = YEAR,                                y = DATA_VALUE,                                color = INDICATOR_NAME,   )) +   ggplot2::geom_point() +   ggplot2::geom_path() +    ggplot2::theme_bw() +   ggplot2::labs(title = "Black Sea Bass Range in Fall (Lat + Lon)",                  x = "Year",                 y = "Range (degrees)") +   ggplot2::facet_wrap('INDICATOR_NAME')

title: Why ESP?
text: development implementation Ecosystem Based Management (EBM) one NOAA’s operating priorities.

title: Why ESP?
text: Integrated Ecosystem Assessment (IEA) seeks improve understanding management fisheries incorporating natural, social, economic data fisheries analyses management plans. Ecosystem Socioeconomic Profiles (ESPs) structured framework facilitate inclusion ecosystem socioeconomic data stock advice process. Generally, ESPs consist three components: 1. Stock metrics: information stock 2. Ecosystem socioeconomic indicators: relevant information ecosystem human dimensions 3. Analysis: Correlation modeling relationships stock metrics ecosystem socioeconomic indicators; summaries current conditions determination qualitative “favorability” stock. Within general framework, ESPs flexible structure allows quantitative qualitative data variety tailored analyses depending stock details. flexibility makes ESPs practicable method implementing Ecosystem Based Fisheries Management Northeast.

title: Why ESP?
text: State Ecosystem (SOE) reports positively received Northeast Mid Atlantic Fisheries Management Councils. However, SOEs general reports easily translate management advice stocks.

what: Ecosystem data on the stock scale
title: Why ESP?
text: ESPs re-calculate SOE data stock scale, allows exploration stock-relevant ecosystem socioeconomic trends.

title: Why ESP?
text: approaching ESP development lens open data science. means process oriented around open access data transparent methods.

title: Why ESP?
text: open source code certainly necessary component reproducible workflow, code without documentation dangerous thing. Although NEesp2 functions data level documentation, function-level documentation obscures forest trees, overall goals purpose NEesp2 package hard identify based package documentation alone. Therefore, vignette outlines high-level organization functionality NEesp2 package goal facilitating use package, well facilitating future updates changes.

title: Why ESP?
text: ESP concept developed Alaska Fisheries Science Center. detailed information, refer reader Kalei Shotwell’s excellent presentation Alaska Fisheries Science Center’s Ecosystem Socioeconomic Profiles (ESPs). purposes applying ESP concept Northeast, identified four major information components ESP: Status stock: compilation relevant ecosystem socioeconomic information give snapshot stock’s current condition. can include qualitative well quantitative information. Alaska ESP calls metrics assessment. Conceptual modeling: conceptual model identifies key linkages bottlenecks affect stock /fishery. step identifies data can give informative knowledge stock. part Alaska ESP’s indicator assessment: indicator suite. Analysis: step can involve multiple analyses varying complexity. Alaska ESP calls analysis step indicator assessment: indicator monitoring analysis, identify three levels analysis: Level 1: minimum, analysis determines recent trends relevant ecosystem socioeconomic data identified conceptual model. Level 2: analysis identifies linkages ecosystem socioeconomic data stock performance. Level 3: Ecosystem socioeconomic data incorporated stock assessment model. Summary: goal ESP inform stock advice, results must communicated clearly succinctly. involves written summary key points implications, well summary visualizations.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Abigail Tyrell. Author, maintainer. Stephanie Owen. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tyrell , Owen S (2025). NEesp2: Generates ESP Reports Northeast. R package version 0.1.1, https://nefsc.github.io/READ-EDAB-NEesp2/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {NEesp2: Generates ESP Reports for the Northeast},   author = {Abigail Tyrell and Stephanie Owen},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.1},   url = {https://nefsc.github.io/READ-EDAB-NEesp2/}, }

title: Generates ESP Reports for the Northeast
text: Ecosystem Socioeconomic Profiles (ESPs) scientific product support Integrated Ecosystem Assessment (IEA). IEA seeks improve understanding management fisheries incorporating natural, social, economic data fisheries analyses management plans. ESPs structured framework developed Alaska Fisheries Science Center integrate ecosystem socioeconomic information stock assessment process.1 adapt ESP process use management Northeast stocks. scientific roadmap consists steps: Review information national initiatives regional priorities determine fish stock priority producing ESP. Determine priority stocks assemble ESP project team. Identify vulnerabilities overfishing, ecological pressures, climate change throughout life stages stock. Combine information ecosystem socioeconomic processes driving stock dynamics. Conduct literature review develop models outlining major environmental economic drivers stock’s distribution, life cycle, fishery. Create, select, analyze monitor suite indicators health stock fishery. Conduct tests trends ecosystem socioeconomic indicators stock metrics. final step culminates stock-specific report presentations concisely convey status leading indicators fisheries scientists managers.

title: Generates ESP Reports for the Northeast
text: Data, functions, report templates aggregated R package, NEesp2. See brief demo use package.

title: Generates ESP Reports for the Northeast
text: package derivative original Northeast ESP R package. relevant data, functions, methods ESP reports prior 2024 found package NEFSC/READ-EDAB-NEesp.

title: Generates ESP Reports for the Northeast
text: package currently development. Standard ecosystem socioeconomic indicator data methods, visualizations, report templates added shortly.

title: Generates ESP Reports for the Northeast
text: repository scientific product official communication National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration, United States Department Commerce. Department Commerce seal logo, seal logo DOC bureau, shall used manner imply endorsement commercial product activity DOC United States Government.

title: Create Chlorophyll-a Indicator — create_chl
text: function generates chlorophyll-indicator OCCCI ERDDAP netCDF file. function passes data EDABUtilities::make_2d_summary_ts, provides summary statistics 2d gridded data time series area. **NOTE: OCCCI DATA WORK EDAB_UTILS. FUNCTION RUN 'DATA_VALUE' NA Converts .nc files data frame.

title: Create Chlorophyll-a Indicator — create_chl
text: data.Either character vector full input file names list spatRasters output.files character vector full output file names corresponding input file shp.file string. Shape file wish crop input file var.name string. Variable name wish extract = 'chl' area.names character vector. Names shape file areas want summarize. statistic string. statistic calculate = 'mean' agg.time character. Time scale calculate (days, doy, months, season, years) tz string. Time zone convert. correction NA touches logical. TRUE, cells touched lines polygons masked, just line render path, whose center point within polygon write.logical. TRUE, write netCDF file output.files. FALSE return list spatRasters

title: Create Chlorophyll-a Indicator — create_chl
text: Saves R object chl, returns chlorophyll-indicator data frame summarized timestep area.names

title: Create Primary Production Indicator — create_pp
text: data.Either character vector full input file names list spatRasters output.files character vector full output file names corresponding input file shp.file string. Shape file wish crop input file var.name string. Variable name wish extract = 'pp' area.names character vector. Names shape file areas want summarize. statistic string. statistic calculate = 'mean' agg.time character. Time scale calculate (days, doy, months, season, years) tz string. Time zone convert. correction NA touches logical. TRUE, cells touched lines polygons masked, just line render path, whose center point within polygon write.logical. TRUE, write netCDF file output.files. FALSE return list spatRasters

what: Create MRIP species recreational effort indicator — create_prop_sp_trips
title: Create MRIP species recreational effort indicator — create_prop_sp_trips
text: function creates indicator proportion trips targeting species interest new data queries, use MRIP Query Tool (https://www.fisheries.noaa.gov/data-tools/recreational-fisheries-statistics-queries) Query 'Time Series' 'Effort Data'. Choose years interest, summarize Annual, Calendar Year, Atlantic Coast State, modes areas Download csv output

title: Create MRIP species recreational effort indicator — create_prop_sp_trips
code: create_prop_sp_trips(   total_trips,   species_trips,   states = c("MAINE", "CONNECTICUT", "MASSACHUSETTS", "NEW HAMPSHIRE", "NEW JERSEY",     "NEW YORK", "RHODE ISLAND", "MARYLAND", "DELAWARE", "NORTH CAROLINA"),   groupby_state = FALSE,   return = TRUE )

title: Create MRIP species recreational effort indicator — create_prop_sp_trips
text: total_trips MRIP trip data (R object mrip_effort) total annual angler trips downloaded csv file species_trips directed trips data species interest (R object rec_trips) function 'create_rec_trips' states States filter data, MRIP query 'ATLANTIC COAST STATE'

title: Create MRIP species recreational effort indicator — create_prop_sp_trips
text: Saves R data object prop_sp_trips
